title: Do cell phone clip camera lenses really enhance the quality of photos? - Quora

response.answer_text: The point of most cell phone lenses is not to enhance the image. There are exceptions where an effect is being added that may enhance the image in certain situations. (Polarized lenses reduce glare. If your shot is suffering from glare, this may help or “enhance”. Starlight filters add starlight effects to the image. If you want this effect then it is an enhancement.) Mostly though the lenses are either the macro, wide angle or telephoto variety. All of these will degrade the image a little because your are putting extra glass in front of your lens. The kits you get for ~$20 are not going to be high grade glass so that goes into your consideration as well. (Of course, you may not notice the effect unless you know what to look for. So don’t be put off cheap lenses just because they are cheap. If they do the job you want them to do, then great.) So why use them? Macro lenses let you focus closer to the object then you would otherwise be able to. This has the effect of making the object look bigger. (This is kind of the point of macro photography, to take pictures of very small things.) Wide angle are like they sound. When you take a pick of something with your phone it only captures a certain angle in front of you. Maybe you want more in your shot and can’t move back. Wide angle lenses help with this. In addition to the distortion you normally get from putting a lens in front of the phone’s lens, wide angle lenses may have a fish eye look. It depends on how strong the wide angle is. Lenses labeled fish eye go for this effect on purpose. Telephoto lenses are the opposite of wide angle lenses. They take a narrow angle and this has the effect of magnifying a distant object. (Think about looking at the moon with your eyes, and then with binoculars. Same idea.)

Clip cellphone camera lenses can help you get sharper photos while giving you more leeway in terms of field of view: Shoot Like a Pro With These Mobile Photography Tips Not all lenses for smartphones are made alike. Some don't make good contact with the smartphone camera, meaning you get fuzzy, out of focus results. Others require you to buy a special phone case so that the lens can attach to it. But this often gets you subpar results because of the lack of a good fit between the phone's lens and the add-on lens. For example, Kenko offers their Real Pro 0.4x Super Wide Lens expands the range of your phone's lens to take wide-angle shots at 165-degrees that are ideal for landscape photography, photos of large groups, and general snapshots. They also offer a fisheye lens with a 180-degree view and a macro/wide angle combination lens with a 120-degree view, so if you get the set, you can pursue all kinds of unique photos with your phone.

Ya It does. I am telling this from my personal experience. I had to travel to Jim Corbett with my college mates and I am very much fond of clicking pictures. I didn't had DSLR that time so I thought of using clip camera lens. At first I didn't thought that it would work so brilliantly. To my knowledge, these lenses are primarily used for focussing on a particular subject and so that does not affect the quality of photos. When selecting a mobile, we should be clear about the quality of pictures taken in the particular instrument. For instance, some high end mobiles may have poor picture quality while lesser known brands can have an amazing picture quality. We should also keep in mind that it is a very wrong idea to use the zoom option in smartphones because it destroys the quality of the pictures taken.

As mostly they are made up of cheap lenses to keep the cost least, cheap lenses do serve the purpose they are meant to be, like the wide angle or the fish eye, but the image quality would be compromised as cheap lenses won't be able to cop up with the quality lenses that most of the smartphones use these days Happy clicking

The lens, sensor and imaging system remain the same.  Those aspects will not change.  Adding another lens system generally introduces some cumulative problems which degrade the photo somewhat.  That said, the lens is generally wide angle and distant objects are very small.  If your objective is to enlarge those objects then an auxiliary lens can be useful in improving your shot sine optical enlargement is superior to digital enlargement (which crops a larger image into a smaller image so that objects remaining appear larger when they are not).

In my experience, the add-on lenses for smartphones are not that great. I tested a telephoto lens for smartphones, and while it did work, it was hard to use and the image quality was degraded by the cheap plastic in the lens (especially anywhere outside of the center of the image).
